The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: This is not just a sequel\, but the continuation of the story from the first game. That’s why it’s called The Last of Us: Part II. I fell in love with the first game. The journey of Joel\, from loving father\, to broken man\, to hardened survivor\, to finally allowing himself to open back up again to this little girl... Ellie made Joel whole again.However\, in Part II\, we get answers to the hard questions we were left with in Part I. How would Ellie respond if she found out the truth about Salt Lake\, and what were\, if any\, the repercussions of Joel’s actions?The monsters in Pittsburgh\, who ambushed Joel and Ellie\, the ones who would murder people in the streets just to take their shoes and whatever else they could find... Joel admits that the reason he knew it was a trap was because he had been on both sides. It’s part of what created such a division between he and Tommy years prior to meeting Ellie. What they had to do to survive was awful. Many innocent people died\, because\, as Joel put it\, it was either them or him.That comes back to haunt him\, in a way that is truly unimaginable to us\, as gamers. And it hurts. What is done to Joel - a character I related with - was so cruel\, and cold\, and ruthless\, and done without a second thought. It’s what puts us in Ellie’s shoes. We want revenge\, and we want it now.However\, what Naughty Dog does so well in this game is to show us that cycle of loss\, revenge and violence\, in a way we never got to see in the first game. The path Ellie takes to get “justice” is paralleled with Abby’s path for “justice” on the man who took her Joel... her father. Abby found him dead in a pool of his own blood\, along with many of the people she called family. They were killed without remorse\, without hesitation\, by a man named Joel Miller.The Last Of Us: Part II forces us to look at its world and see it’s far less black and white than we would have liked to have believed\, even though we knew it wasn’t.In the end\, I knew I didn’t want to see Ellie go down the same path Joel did... and Joel didn’t want that for her either. In fact\, it was the last thing he would’ve wanted. He fought for her\, he did things that\, yes\, were horrible... for her\, so that she could live her life... and he’d do it all over the same way. Because\, to him\, she was his world\, and he wanted her to experience the life that Sarah never got the chance to.In the end... the very end... Ellie saw that. She felt the love Joel had for her\, and it gave her the strength\, in her most darkest moment\, to let go. It’s the same strength Ellie unknowingly gave Joel 4 years prior\, and it was love\, and not revenge\, that granted it.I\, for one\, am glad she found that strength before it was too late.
